page.title: 02Local History-Weoley Castle.
page.content: Weoley Castle-ruins of possibly oldest building in Birmingham. A fortified manor house, not a true castle, it had no keep. Mainly built after the Norman Conquest but with Saxon origins. Name comes from Saxon Â£WEOH-LEAH', a wood in which there is a temple. Three known buildings on the site. Final building consisted of main entrance, chapel, guest house, great hall, kitchen etc, surrounded by moat. Site inhabited for 500 years, a ruin by the 17th century. In care of local authority. Open to public. Place name derivations include naming of city suburb, two schools - Paganel & Jervoise. Bottetourt, Somery & Burnel Roads were named after owners of the castle. The Â£Stonehouse', oldest inhabited building in district, once a farmhouse built with stone from castle ruins. Farmland now part of Weoley Castle Council Estate.
